user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of init_data:
```c
static int
init_data (void)
{
  unsigned int i;

  if (tool_params.medium)
    body_dyn_size = 8U * 1024U;
  else if (tool_params.large)
    body_dyn_size = 1024U * 1024U;
  else
    body_dyn_size = 0;

  if (! init_response_body_data ())
    return 25;

  if (tool_params.unique)
    return 0; /* Responses are generated on-fly */

  if (tool_params.single)
  {
    resp_single = create_response_object ();
    if (NULL == resp_single)
    {
      fprintf (stderr, "Failed to create response.\n");
      return 25;
    }
    return 0;
  }

  /* Use more responses to minimise waiting in threads while the response
     used by other thread. */
  if (! tool_params.thread_per_conn)
    num_resps = 16 * get_num_threads ();
  else
    num_resps = 16 * get_cpu_core_count ();

  resps = (struct MHD_Response **)
          malloc ((sizeof(struct MHD_Response *)) * num_resps);
  if (NULL == resps)
  {
    if (NULL != body_dyn)
    {
      free (body_dyn);
      body_dyn = NULL;
    }
    fprintf (stderr, "Failed to allocate memory.\n");
    return 25;
  }
  for (i = 0; i < num_resps; ++i)
  {
    resps[i] = create_response_object ();
    if (NULL == resps[i])
    {
      fprintf (stderr, "Failed to create responses.\n");
      break;
    }
  }
  if (i == num_resps)
    return 0; /* Success */

  /* Cleanup */
  while (--i < num_resps)
    MHD_destroy_response (resps[i]);
  free (resps);
  resps = NULL;
  num_resps = 0;
  if (NULL != body_dyn)
    free (body_dyn);
  body_dyn = NULL;
  return 32;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
if (tool_params.unique)
    return 0; /* Responses are generated on-fly */
explanation: I flagged fragments that either introduce early unconditional returns (which make subsequent code unreachable for those runtime configurations) or contain non-obvious control-flow that may hide static or inadvertent unreachable code. In particular the cleanup loop using 'while (--i < num_resps)' with an unsigned index is error-prone and should be inspected for off-by-one/underflow conditions that can make the destruction calls unreachable or cause out-of-range accesses. The allocation+for-loop+break sequence and the subsequent 'if (i == num_resps) return 0;' determine whether cleanup code executes; these should be checked to ensure no code paths are inadvertently unreachable (especially when num_resps can be zero or malloc(0) behavior occurs). Other fragments in the function (setting body_dyn_size, the call 'if (! init_response_body_data ()) return 25;', the final frees and returns in normal paths) are straightforward conditional logic or reachable returns and do not, by themselves, constitute statically unreachable code, so they were not flagged.
